headline: Photos: Memorial gathering marks 11 years since Jan. 8 Tucson attack
author: Paul Ingram
sentences: The remembrance ceremony took place at the Historic Pima County Courthouse, which is next to "Embrace," a memorial completed last year for the victims of the Jan. 8, 2011, assassination attempt on U.S. Rep. Gabrielle Giffords that left six dead and 13 wounded.

The event began with a speech from Crystal Kasnoff, the former director the Jan. 8 Memorial Foundation, who spoke along with Jan Lesher, the acting Pima County administrator, about the memorial and its construction.

They were followed by Tucson Mayor Regina Romero, who pressed the need to end gun violence in the U.S., and former congressman Ron Barber, who spoke for a few brief moments and read a prose poem written by a friend.
Last year, organizers for the "Embrace" had hoped to hold a large-scale public event to open the memorial on the 10th anniversary of the attack, but COVID-19 derailed those plans.
For some this was a first chance to see the memorial, and both Barber and Kelly both took a moment to point out details in the design to others.
Before the event began, Giffords and Barber hugged and briefly compared their leg braces, both worn as a consequence of the attack 11 years ago.
A top staffer for Giffords, Barber was shot twice at the 2011 constituent meet-and-greet when it was attacked by a schizophrenic gunman.
A year later, a few people walked along the crunchy gravel rock path into the public space, all wearing masks as required by the county.
